persona.name: Leilani Makanani Kawai

occupation.title: Retired (formerly homemaker, part-time hotel laundry worker, and church volunteer)
occupation.organization: N/A (previously worked at a Waikiki hotel and volunteered at her church)
occupation.description: Leilani is retired and not in the labor force. For most of her adult life, she was a homemaker, raising children and caring for elders in her extended family. She worked part-time in the laundry department of a Waikiki hotel for over 20 years, known for her reliability and gentle manner. She also volunteered at her church, organizing potlucks and helping with Sunday school. Her skills include traditional Hawaiian crafts, basic caregiving, and community organizing. She is not currently employed but remains active in her church and cultural community as her health allows.

persona.residence: Honolulu, Hawaii (urban apartment complex in the Ala Moana district)
persona.education: Attended public school in Honolulu through 9th grade. Left school to help care for younger siblings and grandparents in a multi-generational household. Received informal education in native Hawaiian traditions, hula, and lei-making from elders. Participated in church-based adult literacy classes in her 50s.
long_term_goals: To remain as independent as possible despite health challenges.
To pass on Hawaiian cultural knowledge and family stories to her grandchildren and great-grandchildren.
To complete a marathon in her age group, even if she must walk part of it.
To advocate for better access to healthcare and social services for elders in her community.
To maintain her faith and spiritual practices, blending Christianity and native Hawaiian beliefs.
To ensure her beloved dog, Pua, is cared for if she becomes unable to do so.
To reconnect with estranged family members before her health declines further.
To leave a small financial legacy for her family, despite her current hardships.
persona.style: Leilani speaks softly, with a gentle Hawaiian lilt and a tendency to use Hawaiian words and phrases, especially when expressing affection or gratitude. She is polite, deferential to elders, and rarely interrupts others. Her manner is warm and nurturing, but she can become anxious and apologetic if she feels she has inconvenienced someone. She dresses simply, often in loose muʻumuʻu dresses or athletic wear for running, with a flower tucked behind her ear. She avoids confrontation, prefers to listen rather than speak, and often expresses herself through small acts of kindness. Her hands are expressive, often busy with a lei or rosary. She is formal with strangers but affectionate and teasing with close friends and family. She is self-conscious about her English grammar and sometimes hesitates before speaking in public.

traits: Highly agreeable and compassionate, always seeking to help others.
Deeply cooperative, values harmony and group consensus.
Trusting, sometimes to her own detriment.
High neuroticism: prone to anxiety, especially about health and finances.
Experiences mood swings, sometimes becoming tearful or withdrawn.
Persistent and determined, especially in her running and advocacy.
Resilient in the face of adversity, drawing strength from faith and family.
Sensitive to criticism, easily hurt by harsh words.
Loyal to family and friends, even when relationships are strained.
Tends to ruminate on past losses and regrets.
Finds joy in small pleasures and moments of connection.
Avoids conflict, sometimes suppressing her own needs.
Feels guilt when unable to help others due to her own limitations.
Has a playful, mischievous sense of humor with those she trusts.
Can be stubborn about traditions and routines.

big_five.openness: Moderate. Appreciates new experiences within her comfort zone, especially if they connect to her culture or faith.
big_five.conscientiousness: Low to moderate. Struggles with organization due to health and energy, but is reliable in commitments to others.
big_five.extraversion: Low. Prefers small gatherings and quiet time at home, but enjoys meaningful one-on-one conversations.
big_five.agreeableness: Very high. Compassionate, cooperative, and eager to please.
big_five.neuroticism: Very high. Prone to anxiety, emotional distress, and self-doubt.

interests: Running and walking in Ala Moana Beach Park, especially at sunrise.
Participating in local 10K and half-marathon events, even if she must walk part of the distance.
Watching televised marathons and following elite runners online.
Practicing hula and traditional Hawaiian chants at home.
Making leis for family, friends, and church events.
Attending church services and Bible study groups.
Caring for her dog, Pua, and feeding stray cats in her neighborhood.
Board games with grandchildren, especially checkers and dominoes.
Listening to Hawaiian slack-key guitar and old gospel hymns.
Gardening in pots on her apartment lanai, growing ti plants and plumeria.
Cooking simple, bland meals: rice, poi, boiled chicken, and steamed vegetables.
Watching old episodes of 'Hawaii Five-0' and 'Wheel of Fortune.'
Reading the local newspaper and church bulletins.
Knitting and crocheting small gifts for friends.
Collecting seashells and beach glass.
Volunteering at the church food pantry when able.
Attending community meetings about elder care and affordable housing.
Writing letters to family on the mainland.
Enjoying quiet evenings with a cup of weak tea and her dog.
Looking at old family photo albums and telling stories to grandchildren.
likes: Early morning runs when the air is cool and the park is quiet.
The feeling of accomplishment after finishing a race, regardless of time.
The company of her dog, who sleeps at her feet.
Simple, home-cooked meals without strong spices.
The scent of plumeria and pikake flowers.
Soft, comfortable clothing and slippers.
Listening to rain on the roof.
Receiving handwritten letters or cards.
Watching the ocean and feeling the breeze.
The sound of children laughing.
Attending church potlucks and singing hymns.
The warmth of the sun on her face during walks.
The support of her running group, who encourage her despite her slow pace.
Stories and legends from her elders.
The comfort of familiar routines.
The presence of family, even if only by phone.
The feeling of sand between her toes.
The taste of fresh coconut water.
The security of her faith.
The companionship of her neighbors, many of whom are also elders.
dislikes: Feeling like a burden to others.
The high cost of healthcare and medication.
Being dismissed or patronized due to her age or education.
Technology that is difficult to use.
Being unable to participate in family events due to health.
Feeling left out of decisions that affect her.
The loss of traditional Hawaiian practices.

beliefs: Faith in God is central to her life; she prays daily and attends church as often as possible.
Believes in the importance of ʻohana (family) and kuleana (responsibility) to care for one another.
Sees running as a spiritual practice, connecting her to her ancestors and the land.
Believes that elders have wisdom to share and should be respected and cared for.
Feels that the US government does not do enough to support elders, especially in healthcare.
Advocates for strong government intervention to reduce inequality and provide social services.
Supports environmental protection, especially preservation of Hawaiian land and ocean.
Believes in civil rights and equal treatment for all, regardless of background.
Feels the economy is poor and that her family is worse off than in the past.
Thinks healthcare should be a right, not a privilege, and is frustrated by her inability to afford care.
Believes in the power of community organizing and mutual aid.
Supports the Democratic Party and votes in every election, even if by mail.
Is wary of politicians who promise much but deliver little.
Believes in the importance of both native Hawaiian traditions and Christian faith, seeing no contradiction.
Feels that the US supports Israel about right, but is more concerned with local issues.
Believes that pets are family and should be treated with love and respect.
Thinks that gentrification is eroding the cultural fabric of her neighborhood.
Believes that education is important, even if she did not complete high school.
Feels guilt for not being able to provide more for her children and grandchildren.
Believes that kindness and compassion are more important than material wealth.
Is skeptical of new technology but willing to learn if it helps her stay connected.
Believes that running, even slowly, is a victory over age and illness.
Feels that women, especially older women, are often invisible in society.
Believes in the healing power of nature and the ocean.
Thinks that food should be simple and nourishing.
Believes that everyone deserves dignity, regardless of income or health.
Feels a responsibility to pass on cultural knowledge to younger generations.
Believes that prayer and positive thinking can help in difficult times.
Is concerned about climate change and its impact on Hawaii.
Believes that laughter and music are essential to a good life.
Feels that her worth is not defined by her productivity.
Believes that forgiveness is necessary, even when it is hard.
Thinks that every person has a story worth hearing.
Believes that small acts of kindness can change the world.
Feels that her struggles are part of a larger story of resilience.
skills: Experienced in traditional Hawaiian crafts: lei-making, hula, and basic chant.
Basic caregiving skills: wound care, medication management, and mobility assistance.
Can cook simple, nutritious meals for herself and others.
Knows how to budget and stretch limited resources.
Able to organize small community or church events.
Basic literacy and numeracy, with some difficulty reading complex documents.
Can walk and run at a slow, steady pace, with careful attention to biomechanics.
Understands the basics of injury prevention for older runners.
Can use a smartphone for calls, texts, and simple apps (with help).
Able to advocate for herself and others in healthcare settings.
Good at comforting others and providing emotional support.
Can knit and crochet simple items.
Able to care for pets, including basic grooming and feeding.
Can grow and care for potted plants.
Knows how to access local social services and food banks.
Can write heartfelt letters and cards.
Able to teach grandchildren simple board games and crafts.
Can recall and share family stories and genealogy.
Understands basic first aid.
Can follow a structured training plan for running, adapted for her health.

general: Wakes early, often before sunrise, to walk or run before the heat.
Prays quietly each morning and evening.
Feeds her dog and checks on her plants as part of her daily routine.
Attends church services in person or via radio/TV if unable to go out.
Prepares simple meals, often sharing with neighbors or family.
Calls or texts her children and grandchildren regularly.
Participates in a local running group for seniors, even if she is the slowest.
Volunteers at the church food pantry when her health allows.
Spends afternoons resting, reading, or watching TV.
Takes medication as prescribed, sometimes forgetting doses.
Comfort eats when stressed, favoring bread, rice, or crackers.
Smokes occasionally, especially when anxious or lonely.
Avoids strenuous activity on bad health days, but feels guilty about it.
Writes letters or cards to friends and family.
Tends to her small garden on the lanai.
Plays board games with visiting grandchildren.
Walks her dog in the building courtyard, chatting with neighbors.
Attends community meetings about elder care and housing.
Listens to Hawaiian music or gospel hymns in the evening.
Goes to bed early, often falling asleep while watching TV.

morning: Wakes at 5:30 AM, prays, and stretches gently.
Feeds her dog and waters her plants.
Eats a small breakfast: plain oatmeal or rice with banana.
Walks or jogs in Ala Moana Beach Park, using a slow, careful stride.
Returns home, showers, and changes into a clean muʻumuʻu or athletic wear.
workday: No formal work, but spends time volunteering at church or community center if able.
Prepares lunch: boiled chicken, rice, and steamed vegetables.
Reads the newspaper or church bulletin.
Calls her daughter to check in.
Rests in the afternoon, sometimes napping with her dog.
evening: Prepares a light dinner: soup or poi with bread.
Plays a board game with a neighbor or grandchild if visiting.
Watches TV: local news, 'Hawaii Five-0,' or game shows.
Prays and reflects on the day.
Goes to bed by 9:00 PM, dog curled at her feet.
weekend: Attends church service and stays for fellowship hour.
Participates in a group walk or run if an event is scheduled.
Visits the cemetery to tend to her late husband's grave.
Hosts or attends a small family gathering, bringing homemade food.
Spends quiet time looking at family photos or writing letters.

physical: Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes, managed with medication and diet.
Chronic osteoarthritis in knees and hips, causing pain and limited mobility.
History of hypertension and mild heart failure.
Occasional shortness of breath and fatigue.
Uses a cane on bad days, but tries to walk unaided when possible.
Has lost significant weight in recent years due to illness.
Vision is impaired by cataracts, awaiting surgery.
Hearing loss in left ear, uses a basic hearing aid.
Occasional smoker, especially during periods of stress.
Prone to minor injuries from falls, careful about tripping hazards.
mental: Experiences anxiety, especially about finances and health.
Prone to mood swings and periods of sadness, especially around anniversaries of losses.
Feels isolated at times, but finds comfort in faith and pets.
Uses comfort eating and smoking as coping mechanisms.
medical_history: Hospitalized twice in the past five years for heart-related issues.
Family history of diabetes and heart disease.

relationships.name: Kaleo Kawai
relationships.description: Passed away 8 years ago from heart disease. Was a fisherman and church deacon. Leilani visits his grave regularly and keeps his memory alive through stories.

relationships.name: Malia Kawai
relationships.description: Lives on the Big Island, works as a nurse. Calls Leilani daily and visits monthly. Provides emotional and occasional financial support.

relationships.name: Keoni Kawai
relationships.description: Lives in California, works in construction. Estranged due to past family conflict, but Leilani hopes to reconnect.

relationships.name: Pua
relationships.description: Small mixed-breed rescue, constant companion. Provides comfort and motivation for daily walks.

relationships.name: Aunty Loke
relationships.description: Fellow church member and running partner. Shares meals and helps with errands.

relationships.name: Grandchildren (3)
relationships.description: Visit during holidays and school breaks. Enjoy board games and listening to Leilani's stories.

relationships.name: Church community
relationships.description: Source of spiritual and practical support. Includes pastor, choir members, and food pantry volunteers.

relationships.name: Running group
relationships.description: Local seniors who meet weekly for walks/runs. Provide encouragement and camaraderie.

other_facts: Leilani was born in 1946 in a plantation village on Oahu, the eldest of six children.
Her father was a taro farmer and her mother a seamstress; both spoke Hawaiian at home.
She learned to hula from her grandmother, who was a respected kumu hula (hula teacher).
Left school at 15 to care for siblings and grandparents after her mother fell ill.
Married Kaleo at 19; they lived in a small house near the ocean, raising two children.
Worked part-time in a Waikiki hotel laundry, where she was known for singing while she worked.
Lost her home to a fire in the 1980s, moving into public housing for several years.
Became active in her church, organizing potlucks and teaching Sunday school.
Started running in her late 50s after a church friend invited her to a charity 5K.
Completed her first half-marathon at age 62, walking much of the course but finishing with pride.
Her husband passed away suddenly, leaving her with financial hardship and deep grief.
Adopted her dog, Pua, from a local shelter to combat loneliness.
Struggled with depression after her husband's death, but found solace in running and faith.
Has a small collection of medals from local races, displayed on her bedroom wall.
Once organized a community petition to improve sidewalk safety for elders.
Has a deep fear of hospitals, stemming from negative experiences with her husband's care.
Keeps a journal of family recipes and stories to pass on to her grandchildren.
Was featured in a local newspaper for completing a 10K at age 75.
Has a strained relationship with her son, Keoni, due to past disagreements over money.
Receives food assistance and relies on the church food pantry during hard months.
Has been the victim of a phone scam, making her wary of unknown callers.
Enjoys watching the Honolulu Marathon each year, cheering for runners from her lanai.
Has a favorite running route along the beach, where she greets the same fishermen each morning.
Once saved a neighbor's cat from a storm drain, earning her the nickname 'Aunty Rescue.'
Keeps a rosary and a kukui nut lei by her bedside for comfort.
Has a recurring dream of running effortlessly along the shore with her late husband.
Wears a medical alert bracelet with her daughter's contact information.
Has difficulty affording her medications, sometimes skipping doses to make them last.
Is known for her gentle humor and ability to make others feel at ease.
Has a deep sense of shame about not finishing high school, but is proud of her children's achievements.
Once led a protest against the closure of a local senior center.
Has a favorite bench in Ala Moana Park, where she sits to watch the sunrise after her run.
Keeps a small altar in her apartment with photos of ancestors, flowers, and candles.
Is often asked to bless food at family gatherings, combining Hawaiian and Christian prayers.
Has a habit of humming old hymns while cooking or cleaning.
Dreams of visiting the outer islands one more time before her health declines further.
